segment.source: 5141(S) A directory service object was deleted.
segment.target: 5141(S) A directory service object was deleted.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 5141(S) A directory service object was deleted.
segment.target: Describes security event 5141(S) A directory service object was deleted.

segment.source: 5141(S): A directory service object was deleted.
segment.target: 5141(S): A directory service object was deleted.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time an Active Directory object is deleted.
segment.target: This event generates every time an Active Directory object is deleted.

segment.source: This event only generates if the deleted object has a particular entry in its SACL: the “Delete” action, auditing for specific objects.
segment.target: This event only generates if the deleted object has a particular entry in its SACL: the “Delete” action, auditing for specific objects.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “delete object” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “delete object” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “delete object” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “delete object” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Directory Service:
segment.target: Directory Service:

segment.source: Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of an Active Directory domain, where the object was deleted.
segment.target: Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of an Active Directory domain, where the object was deleted.

segment.source: Type Type = UnicodeString: has “Active Directory Domain Services” value for this event.
segment.target: Type Type = UnicodeString: has “Active Directory Domain Services” value for this event.

segment.source: Object:
segment.target: Object:

segment.source: DN Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of the object that was deleted.
segment.target: DN Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of the object that was deleted.

segment.source: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).
segment.target: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).

segment.source: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.
segment.target: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.

segment.source: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .
segment.target: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .

segment.source: These are examples of RDNs attributes:
segment.target: These are examples of RDNs attributes:

segment.source: • DC - domainComponent
segment.target: • DC - domainComponent

segment.source: • CN - commonName
segment.target: • CN - commonName

segment.source: • OU - organizationalUnitName
segment.target: • OU - organizationalUnitName

segment.source: • O - organizationName
segment.target: • O - organizationName

segment.source: GUID Type = GUID: each Active Directory object has globally unique identifier (GUID), which is a 128-bit value that is unique not only in the enterprise but also across the world.
segment.target: GUID Type = GUID: each Active Directory object has globally unique identifier (GUID), which is a 128-bit value that is unique not only in the enterprise but also across the world.

segment.source: GUIDs are assigned to every object created by Active Directory.
segment.target: GUIDs are assigned to every object created by Active Directory.

segment.source: Each object's GUID is stored in its Object-GUID (objectGUID) property.
segment.target: Each object's GUID is stored in its Object-GUID (objectGUID) property.

segment.source: Active Directory uses GUIDs internally to identify objects.
segment.target: Active Directory uses GUIDs internally to identify objects.

segment.source: For example, the GUID is one of an object's properties that is published in the global catalog.
segment.target: For example, the GUID is one of an object's properties that is published in the global catalog.

segment.source: Searching the global catalog for a User object's GUID will yield results if the user has an account somewhere in the enterprise.
segment.target: Searching the global catalog for a User object's GUID will yield results if the user has an account somewhere in the enterprise.

segment.source: In fact, searching for any object by Object-GUID might be the most reliable way of finding the object you want to find.
segment.target: In fact, searching for any object by Object-GUID might be the most reliable way of finding the object you want to find.

segment.source: The values of other object properties can change, but the Object-GUID never changes.
segment.target: The values of other object properties can change, but the Object-GUID never changes.

segment.source: When an object is assigned a GUID, it keeps that value for life.
segment.target: When an object is assigned a GUID, it keeps that value for life.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically resolves GUID field to real object.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically resolves GUID field to real object.

segment.source: For deleted objects GUID will be resolved to new destination of object, for example: OU=My0ADEL:cc94c0d7-dd53-4061-9791-e53478dbbc3b,CN=Deleted Objects,DC=contoso,DC=local.
segment.target: For deleted objects GUID will be resolved to new destination of object, for example: OU=My0ADEL:cc94c0d7-dd53-4061-9791-e53478dbbc3b,CN=Deleted Objects,DC=contoso,DC=local.

segment.source: To translate this GUID, use the following procedure:
segment.target: To translate this GUID, use the following procedure:

segment.source: Perform the following LDAP search using LDP.exe tool:
segment.target: Perform the following LDAP search using LDP.exe tool:

segment.source: Base DN: CN=Schema,CN=Configuration,DC=XXX,DC=XXX
segment.target: Base DN: CN=Schema,CN=Configuration,DC=XXX,DC=XXX

segment.source: Filter: (&(objectClass=)(objectGUID=GUID))
segment.target: Filter: (&(objectClass=)(objectGUID=GUID))

segment.source: Perform the following operations with the GUID before using it in a search request:
segment.target: Perform the following operations with the GUID before using it in a search request:

segment.source: We have this GUID to search for: a6b34ab5-551b-4626-b8ee-2b36b3ee6672
segment.target: We have this GUID to search for: a6b34ab5-551b-4626-b8ee-2b36b3ee6672

segment.source: Take first 3 sections a6b34ab5-551b-4626.
segment.target: Take first 3 sections a6b34ab5-551b-4626.

segment.source: For each of these 3 sections you need to change (Invert) the order of bytes, like this b54ab3a6-1b55-2646
segment.target: For each of these 3 sections you need to change (Invert) the order of bytes, like this b54ab3a6-1b55-2646

segment.source: Add the last 2 sections without transformation: b54ab3a6-1b55-2646-b8ee-2b36b3ee6672
segment.target: Add the last 2 sections without transformation: b54ab3a6-1b55-2646-b8ee-2b36b3ee6672

segment.source: Delete - : b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672
segment.target: Delete - : b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672

segment.source: Divide bytes with backslashes: b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672
segment.target: Divide bytes with backslashes: b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672

segment.source: Filter example: (&(objectClass=)(objectGUID = b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672))
segment.target: Filter example: (&(objectClass=)(objectGUID = b54ab3a61b552646b8ee2b36b3ee6672))

segment.source: Scope: Subtree
segment.target: Scope: Subtree

segment.source: Attributes: objectGUID
segment.target: Attributes: objectGUID

segment.source: Class Type = UnicodeString: class of the object that was deleted.
segment.target: Class Type = UnicodeString: class of the object that was deleted.

segment.source: Some of the common Active Directory object classes:
segment.target: Some of the common Active Directory object classes:

segment.source: container – for containers.
segment.target: container – for containers.

segment.source: user – for users.
segment.target: user – for users.

segment.source: group – for groups.
segment.target: group – for groups.

segment.source: domainDNS – for domain object.
segment.target: domainDNS – for domain object.

segment.source: groupPolicyContainer – for group policy objects.
segment.target: groupPolicyContainer – for group policy objects.

segment.source: For all possible values of this field open Active Directory Schema snap-in (see how to enable this snap-in: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Cc755885(v=WS.10).aspx) and navigate to Active Directory SchemaClasses.
segment.target: For all possible values of this field open Active Directory Schema snap-in (see how to enable this snap-in: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Cc755885(v=WS.10).aspx) and navigate to Active Directory SchemaClasses.

segment.source: Or use this document: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc221630.aspx
segment.target: Or use this document: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc221630.aspx

segment.source: Operation:
segment.target: Operation:

segment.source: Tree Delete Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Tree Delete Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: Yes – “Delete Subtree” operation was performed.
segment.target: Yes – “Delete Subtree” operation was performed.

segment.source: It happens, for example, if “Use Delete Subtree server control” check box was checked during delete operation using Active Directory Users and Computers management console.
segment.target: It happens, for example, if “Use Delete Subtree server control” check box was checked during delete operation using Active Directory Users and Computers management console.

segment.source: No – delete operation was performed without “Delete Subtree” server control.
segment.target: No – delete operation was performed without “Delete Subtree” server control.

segment.source: Correlation ID Type = GUID: multiple modifications are often executed as one operation via LDAP.
segment.target: Correlation ID Type = GUID: multiple modifications are often executed as one operation via LDAP.

segment.source: This value allows you to correlate all the modification events that comprise the operation.
segment.target: This value allows you to correlate all the modification events that comprise the operation.

segment.source: Just look for other events from current subcategory with the same Correlation ID, for example “5137: A directory service object was created.”
segment.target: Just look for other events from current subcategory with the same Correlation ID, for example “5137: A directory service object was created.”

segment.source: and “5139: A directory service object was moved.”
segment.target: and “5139: A directory service object was moved.”

segment.source:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.
segment.target:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.

segment.source: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.
segment.target: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.

segment.source: Application Correlation ID Type = UnicodeString: always has ““ value.
segment.target: Application Correlation ID Type = UnicodeString: always has ““ value.

segment.source: Not in use.
segment.target: Not in use.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 5141(S): A directory service object was deleted.
segment.target: For 5141(S): A directory service object was deleted.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you need to monitor deletion of Active Directory objects with specific classes, monitor for Class field with specific class name.
segment.target: If you need to monitor deletion of Active Directory objects with specific classes, monitor for Class field with specific class name.

segment.source: For example, we recommend that you monitor for group policy objects deletions: groupPolicyContainer class.
segment.target: For example, we recommend that you monitor for group policy objects deletions: groupPolicyContainer class.

segment.source: If you need to monitor deletion of specific Active Directory objects, monitor for DN field with specific object name.
segment.target: If you need to monitor deletion of specific Active Directory objects, monitor for DN field with specific object name.

segment.source: For example, if you have critical Active Directory objects which should not be deleted, monitor for their deletion.
segment.target: For example, if you have critical Active Directory objects which should not be deleted, monitor for their deletion.
